image.altText: Two men in tan uniforms holding a lead with a large guard dog, walk behind an Aboriginal man at night. Their faces are blurred.

items.synopsis: The public is paying for private security guards to patrol city streets, but they are in the dark about just what powers these guards have been given.

title.children: The city paying private security to patrol the streets like police

image.altText: A young boy with tears on his cheeks is carried by a man out of a van

items.synopsis: In this war between Israel and Hamas, we are in unprecedented territory. The civilian death toll has become so heavy so quickly, and yet Western leaders aren't expressly calling for a ceasefire, writes John Lyons.

title.children: A confronting question that needs an answer: Is the killing of almost 1,000 children a week self-defence?

image.altText: A photo shot from the perspective of an armoured vehicle showing tanks on a beach.

items.synopsis: As Israel releases pictures appearing to show an intent to encircle Gaza's main city, the military says calls for Palestinians to evacuate southward are now "urgent".

title.children: Israel releases images of tanks in Gaza, says call to evacuate southward now 'urgent'

image.altText: A man and a woman sitting in their boot.

items.synopsis: Rural Fire Service Area Director Ross Stacey says that they were able to put in significant fire breaks over the weekend in the bushfire burning near Tara, due to the cooler weather.

title.children: 'No communication': Tara residents say they're being left in the dark over bushfires as crews set to arrive from Victoria

image.altText: A man in a hospital bed, with a canula in his hand, does a hang loose symbol.

items.synopsis: The resounding message of the Safe Work Australia report into silicosis is simple: Ban engineered stone benchtops and save worker lives. So what will make governments act, asks Adele Ferguson.

title.children: 'The only way to stop it is to ban it': The battle to stop engineered stone killing workers

image.altText: Cars stalled in morning peak hour traffic in Annerley, Brisbane

items.synopsis: Authorities give out more than $332 million in fines to speeding drivers in 2022-23 — up 35.7 per cent from the year before — amid heftier penalties.

title.children: Queensland road authorities issue almost $1 million a day in speeding fines

image.altText: Quantam chip

items.synopsis: Quantum computing components are a tenth of a width of a human hair and must be built in an environment 100 times colder than outer space.

title.children: A pair of Queensland researchers are leading the way in the race to build better, cheaper and faster quantum computers

image.altText: A red R-F-S fire truck in front of burning trees.

items.synopsis: A small increase of just 10 to 20 degrees Celsius in the air temperature from one day to the next can play a critical role in determining a fire threat.

title.children: The real reason hot weather leads to bushfires

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: The number of available properties listed to rent fell to a record low in September, with worsening vacancy rates and a rising population increasing competition among renters that's resulting in higher prices.

title.children: The reversal of a pandemic trend has rents soaring again. Is it the new normal or is the end in sight?

image.altText: man on beach holding bottle containing message.

items.synopsis: A beach clean-up crew, and the writer of the note, discourages the use of plastic containers after a message in a bottle is found after a four-month, 400-kilometre journey.

title.children: 'Sorry, guys. Next time I'll use a glass bottle': Message writer apologetic for using plastic bottle

image.altText: Associate Professor Astghik Mavisakalyan

items.synopsis: In early 2024, more than 4.6 million workers are about to find out how much less the company they work for pays female staff. Many companies are working now to fix the problem.

title.children: How to fix the gender pay gap, according to one of the 'bloke-iest' companies in Australia

image.altText: The outline of four women, kept anonymous, superimposed over shattered glass

items.synopsis: Elisabeth Armitage will spend the two next weeks hearing from experts and institutions about where the NT domestic violence system has failed, and how it can improve.

title.children: NT coroner to resume domestic violence inquiry examining killings of four Aboriginal women

image.altText: Olympique Lyonnais coach Fabio Grosso is led down a hallway, holding his face in his hands.

items.synopsis: Italian soccer World Cup winner Fabio Grosso is left bloodied and dazed as fans attack a bus carrying his Lyon team to a match in Marseille.

title.children: French football game called off after fans smash windows on visiting team's bus, leaving coach bloodied

image.altText: Sam Kerr jumps up for headbutt at ball in soccer game

items.synopsis: Hat-tricks to Sam Kerr and Caitlin Foord helped Australia crush the Philippines in front of a record crowd in Perth.

title.children: Matildas defeat Philippines 8-0 in second Olympic qualifier

items.synopsis: Gregory Smith has gone from a homeless forest dweller and a broken man to a PhD graduate, OAM recipient, board member, writer, doting dad and partner. His redemption story is remarkable.

title.children: Gregory Smith became a dad again in his mid-60s. It’s the best thing that’s happened to him

image.altText: A woman in yellow jumper holding shopping bag faces a supermarket shelf full of colourful wrapped foods.

items.synopsis: An RBA rates rise announcement could bring more bad news for people struggling in the cost-of-living crisis. How did we get here and where can you turn for help if you need it?

title.children: With rates tipped to rise yet again, why is it so hard to bring inflation down?

image.altText: Nathan and Sophie Streeter wear Christmassy clothes in a hospital with Charlie laying on Nathan's chest.

items.synopsis: After the Streeters lost their newborn son to necrotising enterocolitis (NEC), they began a journey to build awareness and support for research into the devastating condition.

title.children: Born premature, Charlie had just begun to see 'light at the end of the tunnel'. Then he was hit by a killer disease

title.children: 'Maybe I just miss being called a bogan': From a Hong Kong jail, Gordon Ng writes fondly about his home in Sydney

items.synopsis: Adam Johnson, 29, is being remembered as an outstanding player and incredible person after receiving the fatal injury in a game for the Nottingham Panthers.

title.children: Ice hockey player dead after neck slashed by skate during game in England

image.altText: Cast of Friends walk together.

title.children: He wasn't the smartest, most successful or strongest, but Chandler Bing was an underdog we loved

image.altText: A man wearing a blue and white button up shirt leans his elbow on a fence and looks out over the beach

items.synopsis: Seok Hee Lee grew up in Australia after immigrating from South Korea nearly two decades ago. When his mum applied for a visa, he was considered a dependent child. But after years of waiting for the application to be processed, Mr Lee's application was denied — because he is now an adult.

title.children: Lengthy parent visa processing times poses challenges for children

image.altText: Man stands in military uniform and looks at camera with flags in background.

items.synopsis: In Australia's largest garrison city a foreign defence official will become second-in-command of a combat brigade in a historic appointment.

title.children: Why this first-of-its-kind Australian defence posting is a 'big deal'

image.altText: A white-haired man wearing glasses leans on a balcony railing surrounded by bushland.

items.synopsis: When Michael's wife died in 2016, some of her estate went to a conservation fund. When Michael dies, some of his estate will go to the fund, too. They are among an increasing number of people leaving bequests to environmental causes.

title.children: Would you consider taking care of the environment after you die? Michael has

image.altText: A man wearing glasses and judges' robes looks to the side.

items.synopsis: Women facing domestic violence and other vulnerable people are often left "shattered" by their dealings with family law courts, but a new national program aims to help shelter them from the worst outcomes.

title.children: After watching people left 'shattered' by family law disputes, this chief justice wants to see change

items.synopsis: Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has criticised the government for abstaining from voting a United Nations motion for a truce between Israel and Hamas, labelling the prime minister "weak".

items.synopsis: Charges against the former Liberal Party staffer will this week be back in a Toowoomba court, where his lawyers have indicated he will be fighting the allegations.
